Award.AwardTitle: Developing a Community Information Model and Supporting Software to Extend Interoperability of Sensor and Sample Based Earth Observations
Award.AbstractNarration:
1224638
Horsburgh

This EAR Geoinformatics Program grant supports a two year project to develop a community information model and related software to enable web based interoperability of earth observations derived from sensors and samples that span now discrete data and informatics initiatives for multiple communities. The system would target specific existing web service data repositories in order to demonstrate how the information model can support federation of earth observations data across multiple data publication systems. Specific repositories include the Consortium of Universities for the Advancement of Hydrologic Science, Inc. (CUAHSI) Hydrologic Information System (HIS), EarthChem, the Critical Zone Observatory (CZO) Integrated Data Management System (CZOData), the Integrated Ocean Observing System (IOOS) and the Data Observations Network for Earth (DataONE). The plan calls for collaboration with the related Pis of these projects (through subward support) to improve capture, sharing, and archival these data and associated metadata by building ontologies for describing, encoding and publishing data in common formats to allow interoperability. The plan involves community workshops to engage stakeholders and students in the design of the model. The model would incorporate international standards for data description and publishing utilizing Open Geospataial Consortium standards and domain specific markup languages. It is hoped that the results will feed directly into the larger EarthCube cyberinfrastructure initiative.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientists’ ability to share, discover, interpret, and integrate data is paramount to scientific progress. Specifically, new transdisciplinary approaches in many scientific communities depend on the synthesis of diverse observations of our natural environment from multiple measurements, at multiple scales in time and space, across scientific disciplines, across experimental sites, and from multiple sources. It can be difficult for even highly skilled scientists to discover and access datasets across disparate domain-specific data repositories because each data repository describes, stores, and shares the data in different formats and database structures that make the integration and comparison of the data close to impossible.

This EAR Geoinformatics Program grant supported a collaborative team in the development of a community information model called “ODM2” (ODM = Observation Data Model) and related software that enables easy integration of Earth observations derived from both sensors that generate continuous data stream in the field (‘time-series data’) and samples collected in the field and studied in a laboratory. An information model is used to represent the concepts, relationships, constraints, rules, and operations of data for a chosen scientific domain.  It specifies the information about the data (or metadata) that scientists need to easily describe, publish, discover, access, and interpret the data - for example, the time and location of data collection and the instrument used to collect the data. Our goal was to improve scientists’ ability to capture, share, and archive their data in a consistent manner by standardizing the way observational data are encoded and described, reducing the amount of work required for scientists to find, access, reformat, and manage observational data.

To accomplish our project goals, we held a series of community design workshops that brought together scientists and cyberinfrastructure experts from a range of geoscience domains who jointly identified common and unique characteristics of many types of data commonly created by geoscientists and requirements for describing them. We translated the requirements identified at our design workshops into a single information model that can be used to describe a broad variety of Earth observations data. ODM2 is a comprehensive information model that allows describing observational data with all relevant information that scientists who did not themselves collect the data need to unambiguously interpret and re-use them. We also examined how this much richer description of data could enable new functionality for data publication and discovery within existing data repositories.

We published ODM2 in an open source code repository for broad use by the scientific community. We also developed a suite of open-source software applications that make it easy for data managers and scientists to implement the information model for their data systems, including software that can be used to load and manage observational data. An open-source software development community has been established by this project around these software tools that continues to improve and grow. Multiple cyberinfrastructures within the geoscience domain have adopted the ODM2 information model, including EarthChemDB within the Interdisciplinary Earth Data Alliance, and HydroShare within the hydrological science community.
